bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A.V. McClain, November 27, 1940

div1.p: Hench suggests inserting a series of still photographs into McClain's film in order to record the ceremony at Washington and Jefferson College more fully.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A.V. McClain, November 27, 1940
div1.opener:
November 27, 1940
Mr. A. V. McClain
Washington and Jefferson College
Washington, Pennsylvania
My dear Mr. McClain:
div1.p:
Your local photographer was kind enough to take some movies of the
morning ceremony on Founders' Day, inside the gymnasium, and he also took some
that evening at the banquet. A friend of mine who happened to be there, took
a colored film of the procession, looking toward the gymnasium, which is
rather colorful and includes scenes not taken by your photographer, so far as
I know. I am afraid that the inside scenes, taken in the morning and evening,
are so dark that they are only good for house projection and at rather close
range. I have just spliced the whole film together, and rather than unsplice
it (because I am fairly sure that you will not wish copies) I am sending you
the whole film. You can have it projected, and I am sure you will agree that
these inside scenes are hardly clear enough to show at any large gathering.
I think they would be merely annoyed, and the rest of your nice film would be
spoiled. So far as I am concerned, they are quite all right. I merely project
them at fairly close range in the house, and they are a very nice souvenir.

May I make a suggestion? In order to fill in the continuity of your
own film, may I suggest that you merely have your photographer take successive
moving pictures of the half dozen stills which he took inside the gymnasium, and
if you wish, those at the evening banquet. These stills are very good, and if
only about five feet are shown, the audience will hardly realize they are stills.
When sending stills to the Eastman Co. to have movies made of them, Eastman usually
sends a generous footage of each still, at least ten feet or so. I have found that
this is quite too much, and without motion is boring. About five feet are much
better. If you would like to do this, I shall be glad to pay for that half of
the motion picture footage of the pictures which you will probably discard.
Should you decide to have parts of my movie film duplicated after all, you do
not have to disassemble it. Your photographer can indicate that portion to be
copied, either by a little adhesive strip at the beginning and end of the part
to be copied, or by a thread.
I should appreciate the return of the film at your earliest convenience.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
